questions.question: What is a common symptom of achalasia?
Which radiological investigation is commonly used to diagnose achalasia?
Achalasia primarily affects which part of the gastrointestinal tract?
What is the characteristic finding in an achalasia patient during esophageal manometry?
Which of the following is NOT a treatment option for achalasia?
What does 'LES' stand for in the context of achalasia?
Which anatomical structures are primarily involved in the pathophysiology of achalasia?
options: Lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and the body of the esophagus
questions.correct_answer: Lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and the body of the esophagus

questions.question: Which statement about achalasia's etiology is correct?
options: It is primarily caused by dietary factors
It has a strong genetic basis with a specific gene identified
It involves degeneration of neurons in the myenteric plexus
It is an infectious disease caused by a bacteria
questions.correct_answer: It involves degeneration of neurons in the myenteric plexus

questions.question: A 'wait and see' approach is recommended in the management of achalasia.
Which professional society provides guidelines for the diagnosis and investigation of achalasia?
options: Society of Nuclear Medicine and Molecular Imaging

How can acoustic trauma be prevented?
options: Wearing ear protection in noisy environments
questions.correct_answer: Wearing ear protection in noisy environments

questions.question: Which of the following treatments is NOT typically used for acoustic trauma?
What is the prognosis for patients with acute acoustic trauma if treated early?
options: Good, with potential for full recovery
Fair, with some permanent hearing loss
questions.correct_answer: Good, with potential for full recovery
